THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				James A. Summersett,
      Jr., Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI
  TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal from Charleston County
Â DanielÂ  F. Pieper, Circuit Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2008-MO-025
Heard April 1, 2008 â€“ Refiled July 28,
  2008Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Jack
  B. Swerling, of Columbia, and Katherine Carruth Link, of W. Columbia, for
  Petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General
  Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia, and Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  Petitioner was convicted of murdering his close friend
  Julian Grant a/k/a Dooley and received a life sentence.[1]Â 
  The Court of Appeals affirmed in an unpublished opinion,[2] and we granted his petition for a writ of certiorari.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Petitioner admitted
  that he shot Dooley, but defended on the ground of accident.Â  The State
  presented evidence from which the jury could have concluded petitioner intended
  to shoot Dooley, as well as evidence that petitioner accidentally shot Dooley
  while intending to shoot Jeremy Hawkins a/k/a Scrooge, Dooleyâ€™s cousin.Â  There
  was evidence in the record supporting all three theories, and the case turned
  on witness credibility.
In the late
  afternoon of April 15, 2002, a brawl broke out between petitionerâ€™s cousin and
  Dooleyâ€™s brother.Â  The families were long time neighbors in a Charleston subdivision,
  and the young men were well-acquainted.Â  A second fight then erupted between
  petitionerâ€™s brother and Dooleyâ€™s cousin, Scrooge.Â  Petitionerâ€™s brother was
  armed with a baseball bat given him by petitioner, while Scrooge, according to
  some witnesses, used a gun to pistol whip the brother.Â  Petitioner, who had a
  handgun, admitted approaching the pair and hitting Scrooge, who was winning the
  fight, in the head with the gun.Â  Petitioner claimed to have pulled the gunâ€™s
  hammer back before hitting Scrooge, a move designed to keep the gun from
  accidentally firing as it was being used as a bludgeon.
As petitioner began
  hitting Scrooge, Dooley intervened and pushed petitioner away.Â  According to
  the defense witnesses, after Dooley shoved petitioner, petitioner began to fall
  backwards into a ditch.Â  Dooley reached out to catch petitioner, but petitioner
  hit the ground, the gun discharged, and the bullet hit Dooley who was in the
  act of reaching/falling towards petitioner.Â  The Stateâ€™s eyewitnesses, in
  contrast, testified that petitioner pointed the gun at Dooley, who was shot as
  he backed up with his hands in the air.Â  Other prosecution witnesses testified
  that after the shooting petitioner, who was emotionally distraught, left the
  scene but admitted in phone calls that he meant to shoot Scrooge but
  accidentally hit Dooley. 
Dooley
  was shot in the chest and bled to death.Â  
The
  evidence established that petitioner and Dooley were good friends.Â  Moreover,
  it established pre-existing animosity between Scrooge and petitioner based upon
  Scroogeâ€™s affair with petitionerâ€™s girlfriend/fiancÃ©, and petitionerâ€™s
  subsequent affair with Scroogeâ€™s wife.Â  Animosity existed as well because
  Scrooge had become a federal drug informant.Â  There was also evidence that
  petitioner had threatened Scrooge with a gun the previous Thanksgiving.
ISSUES
The Court granted
  certiorari to consider three evidentiary issues:

	
		
			1) 
			Whether the Court of Appeals erred in finding no 
			reversible error in the trial courtâ€™s ruling permitting the State to 
			cross-examine petitioner about his out-of-wedlock children?
 
		
		
			2)
			Whether the Court of Appeals erred in finding no 
			reversible error in the trial courtâ€™s decision to admit a prior bad 
			act?
 
		
		
			3) 
			Whether the Court of Appeals erred in finding no 
			error in the trial courtâ€™s ruling admitting rap lyrics containing 
			death threats against Scrooge written, sung, and produced in part by 
			petitioner?
		
	

We
  find the Court of Appeals erred in affirming the first two challenged rulings,
  and reverse and remand for a new trial.Â  With regard to the rap lyrics and any
  resulting prejudice, their admissibility at petitionerâ€™s next trial will
  depend, in large part, upon the evidentiary showing made in that proceeding.Â 
  Accordingly, we do not address the merits of that issue here, but admonish the
  State and the circuit court upon retrial to exercise caution if this issue is
  raised.
Impeachment/Character
  Evidence
On direct
  examination, petitioner testified to his activities on April 15, 2002,
  including references to taking his son Ques to school, and to planning to pick
  him up afterwards as he â€œnormallyâ€ did.Â  Petitioner explained that he did not
  attend Quesâ€™ late afternoon baseball game as he â€œnormallyâ€ did because of car
  trouble.Â  This testimony was offered to explain why petitioner had a baseball
  bat in his automobile which he acknowledged giving to his brother.
The
  Stateâ€™s cross-examination of petitioner commenced with this exchange:

	
		
			Q. 
			All right, [petitioner].  By way of 
			background, letâ€™s get some clarity on some of these things.  
			You were talking about you have one child?
		
	
	A.     No.
	Q.     You actually have five children;
  donâ€™t you?
	A.     Six.
	Q.     Six children?
	A.     Yes.
	Q.     By how many different women?
	A.     Five.
	Q.     So you have six children by five
  different women?
	A.     Yes.
	
		
			Q. 
			Okay.  Have you ever had any of those children 
			while you were in wedlock with your wife?  Did you ever have 
			any children out of wedlock?
		
	


	A.     Iâ€™m not legally married.
	Q.     Okay.Â  So you just have children
  ---
	(Petitionerâ€™s
  Attorney):Â  Objection.Â  If we could approach.

A
  bench conference followed during which petitionerâ€™s attorney objected, saying
  â€œIâ€™m aware this is cross-examination but this seems like it is more character
  evidence.â€Â  The solicitor responded that his question was proper because (1)
  petitioner â€œput his character on the standâ€ (2) [petitioner had claimed to be]
  â€œgood family man with one child and all of the testimony has been about the one
  childâ€ and (3) â€œthere had [already] been a lot of testimony about adultery in
  the evidence.â€Â  Petitionerâ€™s attorney pointed out, however, that the solicitor
  had not objected to his cross-examination of various Stateâ€™s witnesses about
  their adultery, to which the solicitor responded â€œBecause it is relevant.â€ 
The judge found the
  solicitorâ€™s cross-examination proper because petitioner had been portrayed â€œas
  if he is a good person and he only has one child.â€Â  The State reinforced the trial
  judgeâ€™s misimpression that petitioner had testified he only had one child: although
  petitionerâ€™s attorney pointed out petitioner had never so testified, his
  objection to this line of questioning was overruled.Â  The interrogation
  continued, during which, among other things, the solicitor challenged
  petitioner to name the mothers of his children.
The Court of
  Appeals held that petitionerâ€™s attorneyâ€™s objection to the cross-examination
  may have been untimely, and thus the propriety of the cross-examination may not
  have been preserved for appellate review.Â  We disagree.Â  The cross-examination
  began with an unusual series of questions and it was not immediately apparent
  that the solicitor was delving into the number of petitionerâ€™s children and his
  relationship with them and their mothers.Â  We find the objection was timely.
Next, the Court of
  Appeals found that it was unnecessary to decide whether petitioner put his
  character trait as a good father in issue during his direct examination or
  whether he had merely been testifying to a narrative of events. We find
  petitioner did not put his character as a good father in issue. Moreover, while
  the number of children and mothers is undoubtedly probative of petitionerâ€™s
  fertility, and may raise doubts about his commitment to societal conventions,
  it sheds no light on whether or not he is a good father to those children.Â  Â Even
  if petitioner had put this character trait in issue, the cross-examination was
  not relevant.Â  
Before
  this Court, the State has taken a different tack, arguing that the evidence was
  elicited not as character evidence but rather to impeach petitionerâ€™s
  testimony.Â  We are unable to discern what in petitionerâ€™s direct testimony was
  impeached by the evidence of his six out-of-wedlock children and their mothersâ€™
  names.
The ultimate ruling
  by the Court of Appeals was that any error in permitting this testimony was
  harmless in light of the other evidence of petitionerâ€™s promiscuity, that is,
  that petitioner had had a sexual relationship with Scroogeâ€™s wife.Â  We are not
  confident that a single adulterous relationship equates to â€œpromiscuityâ€ in the
  same sense that fathering six children by five different women does, and thus do
  not agree that this evidence was harmless because it was merely cumulative to
  other evidence of promiscuity.
In short,
  petitioner did not put his character as a good father in issue, nor is evidence
  that he has fathered six children by five mothers probative whether he is, in
  fact, a good father.Â  Further, adultery with a married woman does not make one
  â€œpromiscuousâ€ as that term is commonly understood and thus the evidence of
  petitionerâ€™s out-of-wedlock children was not cumulative to the evidence of his
  adultery.Â  The Stateâ€™s cross-examination was not designed to elicit any evidence
  probative either of petitionerâ€™s guilt or of his credibility, but rather was
  intended solely to paint him as a person who does not respect societal norms,
  and to suggest that he was an irresponsible individual who did not even know
  the names of his childrenâ€™s mothers.Â  The circuit court erred in allowing this
  questioning, and the Court of Appeals erred in deeming it â€œcumulative.â€Â  We
  find both error and prejudice.Â  We need not decide, however, whether this error
  alone would warrant reversal in light of a second erroneous evidentiary ruling by
  the trial court.
Other Bad Acts
As
  mentioned above, the State presented two different theories: either petitioner
  intentionally shot Dooley, or Dooley was hit as petitioner targeted Scrooge.Â 
  Petitionerâ€™s defense theory was accident; that is, that the gun discharged
  accidentally when he hit the ground as he fell backwards. 
In 1993, petitioner
  fired a shot which struck an acquaintance of petitionerâ€™s, Ernest Riley, in the
  foot.Â  Petitioner was charged with assault and battery with intent to kill in
  connection with that shooting, and eventually pled nolo contendre to the
  charge.Â  The State sought to introduce evidence of this event under Rule
  404(b), SCRE and State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923), to
  show the absence of accident or mistake in the Dooley shooting.Â  
The
  issue arose after attorney Thrower testified as a defense witness to
  post-shooting telephone conversations on April 15 in which petitioner
  maintained he had accidentally shot and killed Dooley.Â  Before beginning
  Throwerâ€™s cross-examination, the State sought a ruling whether it could examine
  Thrower about the Riley case in which he had represented petitioner.Â  The State
  maintained the Riley shooting was probative of petitionerâ€™s current claim of
  accident because he had previously claimed that the shooting of Riley, also an
  acquaintance, was likewise an accident.Â  Petitionerâ€™s counsel protested that,
  among other things, in this case petitioner claimed to have accidentally fired
  the gun, while in the Riley case he admitted intentionally shooting at the
  ground, but that Riley was accidentally injured when the bullet ricocheted and
  hit his foot.Â  Moreover, the State argued â€œsimilarityâ€ in that both shootings
  took place in the Orleans Wood subdivision, in both cases petitioner fled from
  the scene, and in both cases he subsequently maintained in phone conversations
  that the shooting was accidental.Â  Petitionerâ€™s attorney protested that these
  were completely separate incidents, and that petitioner was not using
  â€œaccidentâ€ in its legal meaning.Â  The judge eventually ruled that the Riley
  shooting admissible to show an absence of mistake or accident in the Dooley
  shooting.
Thrower then
  testified before the jury to the facts, as he recalled them, surrounding the
  1993 Riley shooting, but his recollection was vague.Â  The State later called
  Riley.Â  He testified that petitioner had gotten in a fight with Rileyâ€™s
  fiancÃ©eâ€™s sister and pulled a gun on her.Â  Riley â€œconfrontedâ€ petitioner about
  this incident, and two days later petitioner â€œconfrontedâ€ Riley, and pulled a
  gun on him, pointing it at Rileyâ€™s head.Â  Riley testified he told petitioner to
  go ahead and kill him, since everyone knew petitioner carried â€œa little .22
  that would usually crap on himâ€ and therefore was not afraid.Â  In fact, it was
  as petitioner was pointing the gun down that it fired: the bullet hit the
  ground and ricocheted up, hitting Riley in the heel.
The Riley shooting
  is not probative whether the Dooley shooting was an accident, intentional, or
  unintentional.Â  The facts of these two shootings are not analogous to a
  situation where, for example, a man who is on trial for shooting and killing
  his second wife claims accident, having previously â€œaccidentallyâ€ shot and
  killed his first spouse.Â  Here, there is no â€œlogical relevanceâ€ between the two
  shootings. State v. Lyle, supra; State v. Braxton, 343
  S.C. 629, 541 S.E.2d 833 (2001).
The admission of
  the Riley shooting was prejudicial error and the Court of Appeals erred in
  deferring to the trial judgeâ€™s discretion in admitting this evidence.Â  This
  error alone, but especially in combination with the improper cross-examination
  of petitioner, requires we grant a new trial on both charges.Â  Accordingly, the
  decision of the Court of Appeals affirming petitionerâ€™s convictions and
  sentence is
REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BEATTY, JJ., concur.



[1] He was also convicted of possession of a firearm during the commission of a
  crime of violence but received no separate sentence.
[2] State v. Summersett, Op. No. 2005-UP-373 (S.C. Ct. App. filed June 10,
  2005) (App. pp. 819-827).
